Could a miner cause some portion of the network to fall off the chain in this manner?  I guess we assume clocks are well synced.  Could this be an attack vector against a node is one could change their system time?

~~Did you try deleting last block and `-rescan`?~~

> Did you try deleting last block and -rescan? 

Please ignore that advice.

You can't delete a block without corrupting the database, and `-rescan` has only an effect on the wallet. The problem here seems to be with the block downloading logic.

@nathaniel-mahieu I saw this "bug" last week in the source code, but I have been unable to reproduce it on regtest, so I assumed it was just me not reading the code correctly. (My test fired the rule violation, waited 10 sec, re broadcasted, and checked if the node reconsidered, and it worked fine)
Might be related to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8411#issuecomment-238035612 (not about this particular rule though)

I'm not sure that this is a bug, although I do think that it could be quite simple to get bitcoind to automatically reconsider the highest block upon startup, or whenever invalid blocks are seen. Either of these solutions would fix this, I think.

@nathaniel-mahieu regarding attack vectors, yes, I think there may be a risk here in that with eclipse attacks the adjusted time could be influenced and cause a node to stop updating. With various fixes around, such as #8282 to help improve address management, and perhaps this combined with having the "adjusted time" influenced only by outbound connections (perhaps this is already what is done?), then this scenario would be much less likely to happen as far as I can see.
